div1.p: CONSULAT GENERAL DE L'ETAT INDEPENDENT DU CONGO. BALTIMORE.
le 22 janvier 1907
Monsieur le Chevalier- J'ai l'honneur de vous transmettre des deux "memorandum" sur le mouvement catholique que j'ai envoyé au Baron Moncheur et au Roi.
La mouvement a eu une pleine reussite. Comme vous voyez par "le memorandum" nous avons déjà gagné l'appris
de plus de deux million citoyens americains, il n'y a pas du doute c'est la force du catholique qui a l'attitude du gouvernment americain.
Veuillez agreer, Monsieur le Chevalier, l'assurance de ma consideration la plus distinguée. James Gustavus Whiteley
Consulat Général De L'État Indèpendant Du Congo, Baltimore.
Memorandum on the Catholic Movement in Favor of Congo.

The "Congo Reform Association" has from the beginning, made its campaign on religious lines. Its agents here are all protestant ministers, they hold their meeting in churches and use the societies and organizations of these churches to gather petitions, to form committies and to carry on their propaganda. It is they who have made it a religious war and they have been trying to prevent the Catholic Church from realizing that they have declared war, while they know that the organization of the Catholic Church is the most powerful body that could oppose them. The Church has, however, been on guard for the past two years. In December, 1904, I was invited to attend a council of the most important dignitaries and laics of the Church to tell them the Congo situation and since that time they have stood ready to help us if the necessity should arise.

We had hoped to be able to manage the campaign alone without their open aid, and we could have done it not been for this unfortunate Kowalski-Wack affair. The scandal created by the publication of that affair almost absolutely tied the hands of our friends in the Senate and created a prejudice against us in the minds of Senators who otherwise would have been indifferent or even friendly. Our enemies, taking advantage of the moment, were pushing the Lodge Resolution. The only thing to prevent the
adoption of that resolution was to bring some new and powerful force to our aid, and the most powerful organization available was our natural ally, the Church. Fortunately at that moment our enemies made the mistake of openly attacking the Cardinal Gibbons. That gave us an opening. The Cardinal replied to the attack by a strong defense of the King-Sovereign's administration. The statement was published all over the country and immediately had a good effect not only upon Catholics but also upon protestants, for the Cardinal is greatly admired and respected by all creeds. The newspapers referred to the Cardinal's utterance in their editorials and became more cautious and conservative in regard to intervention in the Congo. The statement had also undoubtedly a very favorable effect on the Government at Washington and we have reason to believe that since that statement appeared (post hoc ergo propter hoc) the President has taken a more favorable attitude. There is no doubt that the President and his party pay great heed to the opinion of the Cardinal and of the Catholic hoping to gain the political support of the Catholic vote.

The statement of the Cardinal was not enough, however. It motified the attitude of the Government, but according to the views of the most astute politicians among our friends, there was every probability that the Lodge Resolution would be adopted by the Senate Committee. The only card left for us to play (and it is the card most feared by our enemies) was the influence of the Catholic Church.

The Catholic Church represents to the American politician powerful factor in the politics and a great number of votes. It is the only thing to offset the numerous petitions coming into the Senate from small Baptists, Presbyterians and other churches which also represent votes to the politician. The politician is governed by fear of his electors. If he is petitioned by a number of his electors from small Baptist churches to meddle with the Congo he will be inclined to do it unless he is made aware that he will offend other voters. We had to make him aware of this. Calling to our aid the Catholic societies with their large membership of American voters was our only chance to restrain the Senate from rash action against us. It is well known in the United States that every politician is afraid to meddle with any question which may offend Catholic votes.

This step was thought a wise political move by our friends here who best understand the politics of this country. Baron
Moncheur and I cabled what steps we were about to take and received no objections form Brussels. I obtained the approval and support of the Highest dignitaries of the Church and then immediately started to set in motion our friends of the Catholic, Belgian and Irish societies throughout the country so that they might protest to the American Government against intervention in Congo affairs. Fortunately the Senate had adjourned for a holiday of two weeks at Christmas. This gave me time, by travelling night and day to cover several thousand mils of territory, to communicate with such men as Archbishop Messmer, Bishop McFaul, Bishop Fox, Bishop Maes and about ten other Bishops besides laics of importance and also with the heads of various societies of laymen and with other organizations.

As a result there have been placed before the President and the Government and before the Senate (upon the reassembling of the Senate a few days ago) petitions in our favor from individuals and societies representing nearly two million American citizens urging the American Government to refrain from any interference with the Congo.
As well as I can ascertain the following petitions representing the sentiments of nearly two million are by this time already before the Government and Congress:

list.item: Amiercan Federation of Catholic Societies representing 1,500,000 members
Order of Foresters representing 125,000 members
Catholic Knights of St. Louis
Belgian Society of Chicago
Belgian Protective Society of Denver
Belgian Protective Society of New York
Belgian Union of New York
Belgian Beneficial Society of New York
Several Catholic Societies of Rochester, State of New York.
Individual letters from influential citizens, bishops, laics, &c. to the President, the Secretary of State and Senators.
Petitions and protests from 700 or 800 citizens of Denver, New York, Rochester, Louisville and Philadelphia.

div1.p: This expression of sentiment in our favor is now before the American Government representing nearly two million American citizens.
In addition we expect that in the next few days there will reach the American Government the Senate petitions in our favor from:-

list.item: The Federation of the State of New York
The Federation of the County of New York
About 40 different societies in New York and Brooklyn
About 400 or 500 individual citizens of New York
About 200 or 300 citizens of Chicago
Ancient Order of Hibernians representing 250,000 members
Central Verein representing 100,000 members
Catholic Bortherhood of America representing 65,000 members
Catholic Knights of America representing 20,000 members
Western Catholic Union representing 7,000 members
Bohemian Catholic Union representing 10,000 members
Catholic Knights of Ladies of America representing 8,000 members
Women's Catholic Order representing 50,000 members
Irish Catholic Union representing 10,000 members
44 Federation Societies in 44 different States representing 10,000 members

div1.p: The above societies are expected not only to petitions in favor of the Congo to the President, the Secretary of State and the Senate Committe on Foreign Affairs but also to write to the Senators form their respective States.

This is a powerful movement we have started. It gives us the most powerful support we can have. It will not lose us any of our protestant supporters and it can cause no harm to any one except to the enemies of the Congo. Our Catholic support cannot in any way cause embarrassment to the American Government, if that Government is well disposed toward the Congo. It is possible that the American Government, if it wishes to meddle in the Congo, should have preferred that we should not make any resistance or any show of strength. If the American Government is well disposed toward us it will be glad to see us bring our all our forces for this will strengthen the American Governments hand against the anti-Congo agitators. The only real objection the American Government could have to such a demonstration is that (if it is illdisposed towards us) fear of the Catholic vote would prevent it from carrying out its intention and from taking on extremely hostile attitude towards us.
It will be observed that in all this movement I have kept in the background and made it appear that the Catholic movement was entirely spontaneous.

Our movement may not be entirely successful. We are working against great odds on account of the Kowalski-Wack affair. If we succeed it will be snatching victory out of defeat. In any case, even if the Lodge Resolution is adopted, the fact that we have Catholic support will undoubtedly prevent the American Government from any extremely aggressive movement which it might wish to take.
James Gustavus Whiteley
Seventh January.
Massachusetts Catholic Order of Foresters.
Boston, Mass., Jan. 16, 1907.
His Majesty, King Leopold, Belgium
His Majesty:-
The High Standing Committee of the Massachusetts Catholic Order of Foresters, representing 100,000 souls, in meeting assembled January 14th, 1907, endorsed the following resolution:-
WHEREAS it has come to our knowledge that accusations have been made against King Leopold's administration of the Congo Free State.
WHEREAS we believe that these accusations are unfounded and are inspired by religious jealousy and by the desire of a certain strong nation to extend its power in Africa.
Be it resolved, and it is hereby resolved:

That we deprecate the use of means such as have marked the action of our protestant bretheren in this matter; the defaming of an individual is a serious breach of Christ's Commands; the defaming of a whole nation and of a Christian King is most serious.

Resolved, second, that relying on the testimony of trustworthy Catholic Bishops and missionaries in the Congo, of travellers who have visited the country and who know the actual conditions prevailing there, and of the impartial commissioners who recently reported on the subject, we see no greater reason
for an international investigation of King Leopold's rule in the Congo than for an international investigation of the administration of any other Power in Africa.
Resolved, third, that no body of men will go farther to redress the human misery than members of this organization.
Resolved, fourth, that we extend to the caluminated King our sympathy with him in this matter in which he has been so unjustly occused.

Resolved, fifth, that copies of these resolutions be sent to the President of the United States, the Secretary of State, the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, the two Senators from Massachusetts, and to His Majesty, King Leopold.

Attest--
(signed) John J. Leonard
High Secretary-Treasurer.
Report on Visit to Boston and New York, January 11-18, 1907.

The Catholic movement seems to have produced the most excellent results upon the President and the Secretary of State as well as upon the Senate, and I am specifically glad to be able to report the success of my mission to Boston which is not only the centre of the anti- Congo agitation but is also the home of the electors of Senator Lodge who has brought in the Resolution against us.

Boston is the centre of the Baptist missionary societies and of many fantastic "reforms" movements but there is also a strong and growing Catholic element there whose influence in politics is sought even by Senator Lodge and other "puritans". During my visit to Boston I have been fortunate enough to interest their strong Catholic element in our cause and to arouse them to active work in our behalf.

His Grace, Monsignor O'Connell, Archbishop of Boston, received me most sympathetically and has promised me his support. The Catholic "Federation" of that district has already sent to the President and to the Senate a petition in our behalf.

Last Monday night in Boston I met the High Council of the Massachusetts Catholic Order of Foresters, which represents one hundred thousand of Senator Lodge's electors and as a result, chiefly through the sympathetic aid of the Rev/Father O'Neil, Spiritual Advisor of the Order, they took up the cause of the Congo and adopted resolutions in our favor which were at once transmitted to the President of the United States, the Secretary of State, to the Senate, to Mr. Lodge, and other
Senators. The Order of Foresters also desire that a copy of their resolution should be presented to His Majesty, and I have the honor to transmit a copy herewith, with the suggestion that some acknowledgment and response be sent the Order through us, as soon as possible.

The Boston "Alumni Sodality" also took a great interest in the matter. The question was presented to them through the Rev. Father Dennis T. O'Sullivan who has spoken publicly in favor of the Congo on several occasions. I understand that the "Alumni Sodality" is sending to the Government petitions in our favor as a society and that the individual members are also working for us.

The Catholic Union which has among its members some of the most important Catholic citizens of Boston has also taken up our cause. They will have a lecture and discussion on the Congo as soon as possible and will then probably adopt resolutions similar to the resolutions adopted by other Catholic societies. The President of the Catholic Union has taken a person interest and may be expected to aid us in every way possible.

The "Federation" of Boston is to hold a meeting tonight (January 20) to discuss the French Church question and also the Congo and still further action may be expected from them to promote our interests.

I also had several meetings with Mr. Matthew Cummings, the President of the Irish Society known as the "Ancient Order of Hibernians". He is an important politician in Boston and the Hibernians constitute a well-known and influential society of about two hundred thousand men. He manifests a deep interest in our case and promised me to bring the matter up before the High Council of the Order last night, when they probably will have adopted resolutions in our favor to be sent to the President, Secretary of State and the Senate.

It seems thus that we have aroused a strong element in our favor in Boston and have, by my visit there, secured the active help of between three hundred thousand and four hundred thousand of Mr. Lodge's own electors. This is sure to have a good effect on Lodge as well as us on the other Senators. We have secured a strong support even in the midst of the enemy's camp.
In addition to this aid from the State of Massachusetts I have been able, through the help of the Rev. Father Shanley, to secure important assistance from the neighboring State of Connecticut.

Petitions to the President and to the Senate were sent, at my request, form several Catholic Association of that State, among others from the "St. Peters Corporate Society" numbering nearly five thousand members, and the matter is brought to the attention of other societies which may be expected to act soon.

In addition to these societies I was enabled while on this trip to get into communication with the "Catholic Young Men's National Union" numbering fifty thousand, which without loss of time, sent an expression of its sentiments in our favor to Washington by telegram.

Father Shanley also requested the "Catholic Temperance Association Union of America" which has ninety thousand members to take similar action. I have not yet received official notice but it is probable that they have taken the requested action by this time.
In New York I found that the agitation which we had started amont the Catholic societies is still continuing satisfactorily and I am endeavoring to encourage the movement there as much as possible.

The Catholic movement has not only intimidated our enemies in the Senate and encouraged our friends in the same body, but it has also encouraged our friends everywhere and especially our friends in the new Concessionary companies who seem now disposed to work harder for us politically than they were four years ago at the time of the Kowalski-Wack publications. I seized the opportunity while in New York to urge them to greater endeavor. I think that the very fact of the existence of the American Concessionary Companies has been an influence in our favor and has had some effect in making the Government and the Senate more conservative but I hope now to get the people interested in the companies to work more actively. At my suggestion the American-Congo Company has employed as one of its agents Mr. S. P. Verner, who has been in the Congo several years and whose name is well known to the Chevalier de Cuvelier. As Verner is impartial and honest and knows about the true condition of the Congo I have urged upon the Company that they should allow Verner to go to Washington at once and see the President, the Secretary of State and various Senators in order to put the true state of affairs before them.
I have found every where I have been in this country in the past four weeks that the defence of the King Sovereign's administration by Cardinal Gibbons has made a deep and lasting impression.

I feel assured that it is the Catholic movement that has held the Senate in check for the past several weeks. The Resolutions of Societies, and the petitions of individuals, as well as certain person influence and personal letter written by friends of Senators have undoubtedly produced a very favorable effect. If we can continue the movement with sufficient vigor we may be able to avert any action by Congress, but, in any event, the expression of opinion which we have placed before Congress and before the Government is sure to have a decided effect in modifying any hostile action which the Government may have momentarily contemplated while under the pressure of the Baptist and other Protestant missionaries.

While on this trip in the North I have still continued to keep in communication with the individuals and societies in the West whom I visited two weeks ago, and I shall continue to encourage them to keep up the movement they have started in favor of the Congo.

James Gustavus Whiteley
Consul General.
CONSULATe GENERAL OF THE CONGO FREE STATE. BALTIMORE.
January 22 1907
Monsieur le Chevalier- I have the honor to to transmit to you the two "memorandums" on the catholic movement that I sent to the Baron Moncheur and to the King.
The movement had a full success. As you see in "the memorandum" we already won l'appris
of more than two million american citizens, there is no doubt it is the force of the catholic that the attitude of the american government.
Please accept, Mister Knight, the assurance of my most distinguished consideration. James Gustavus Whiteley
